message.content:
We first note that the “Initial” transaction row for fixed assets reads: 

  Initial20231231001 | Fixed Assets … with an amount of 5000000.0

This is the beginning “book‐value” of Fixed Assets on 2023‑12‑31.

Then – in the many transactions – we look for any transaction whose type is “Fixed Assets Purchase” (which record additions to fixed assets). In our data there are two such transactions:

1. A FixedAsset20231231001 row with:
  amount = 321724.42  
  (asset_name “Processing Equipment4”, asset_type “Processing Equipment”)

2. Another FixedAsset20231231001 row with:
  amount = 115740.01 
  (asset_name “Production Line5”, asset_type “Production Line”)

We add these two purchase amounts:  
  321724.42 + 115740.01 = 437464.43

Then the Fixed Assets ending value is the initial fixed assets added by the new purchases:
  5000000.00 + 437464.43 = 5437464.43

Note that even though a Depreciation transaction is present, in our balance‐sheet “fixed assets” item (at least as it is recorded in the problem) we consider the purchase additions on top of the initial cost.

Thus our answer is:

{
  "solution": {
    "Fixed Assets Initial Value": "5000000.00",
    "Fixed Assets End Value": "5437464.43"
  }
}
